<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
REAL ESTATE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/01/pacaso-emerges-stealth-17m?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Seeking Buyer for Original Pacaso
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Pacaso house" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNTk3L3BhY2Fzb19ob3VzZS5wbmciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Will Varner</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Signs you've made it: Three-ply toilet paper, ordering from a menu that doesn't have prices, and stepping into the foyer of your second home. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, startup Pacaso <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/as-pandemic-boosts-suburban-home-demand-startup-sells-a-new-ownership-model-11601553600?mod=business_featst_pos2&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">emerged from stealth</a> to help you with pad No. 2. The brainchild of former Zillow CEO Spencer Rascoff and exec Austin Allison, Pacaso is pitching "an entirely new category of second home ownership" by selling <a href="https://www.geekwire.com/2020/ex-zillow-leaders-including-spencer-rascoff-launch-startup-change-people-buy-second-homes/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">partial rights</a> to a property, ranging from 12.5%–50%.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How it works: </strong>Imagine that a timeshare, commercial lease, and Airbnb had a baby. Interested buyers browse Pacaso's listings or find something on the market, then the company sets up the LLC, finds buyers for remaining shares, and handles the other logistics. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>In exchange, Pacaso charges an upfront 10% fee and 1% annual maintenance fee.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Pacaso launched with just four homes, but it's hoping to spread to 25 markets in the next year with a focus on suburbs and more affordable cities rather than beachfronts and resort towns. It's got $17 million in venture funding, including the backing of former Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz, and $250 million in debt.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">There are still some questions.</strong> Like traditional vacation timeshares, Pacaso properties could see slower appreciation compared to a fully owned home, as well as bitter competition over who gets the house for the Fourth of July weekend. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Timing couldn't be better </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Rascoff and Allison wanted to "democratize" second homes before the pandemic, but Covid-19 offered a perfect opportunity as city residents looked to swap subways for suburbs or upgrade their WFH offices. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Home prices are now up 13% annually after four months of growth in new home sales and a <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/24/2020-residential-real-estate-sales-soar-mortgage-delinquencies?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">supply squeeze</a> that's limiting inventory. Pacaso thinks it has the solution: Besides defraying the cost of home ownership, it would bring new units on the market by buying portions of existing second homes.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>real estate experts think home buying enthusiasm could continue <a href="https://www.axios.com/real-estate-market-819e3c85-3765-4014-91c0-b545be6d5935.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">for years</a> thanks to low interest rates and older millennials settling down with their first mortgage.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RETAIL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/01/bed-bath-beyond-surges-much-33-strong-earnings-report?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Michael Corleone of the Mall
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="A Bed Bath & Beyond storefront " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNTk4L2JlZF9iYXRoX2JleW9uZC5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>John Nacion/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Just when you thought Bed Bath & Beyond was out, pandemic trends and new leadership pulled it back in.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory: </strong>Bed Bath & Beyond was in a bad way last year, with <a href="https://finance.yahoo.com/news/bed-bath-beyond-verge-epic-151648613.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">an ugly brawl</a> between activist investors and the executive team. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But now? That investor tussle ended in <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/retail/stories/2019/12/18/bed-bath-beyond-sheds-csuite?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">a c-suite shakeup</a>, including a new CEO, that's serving it well. The new guy, Mark Tritton, released quarterly earnings yesterday that beat expectations on both revenue and profit. Shares surged as much as 33%. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So what happened? </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>People stuck in their </span><span><span style="text-decoration: line-through;">Covid caves</span></span><span> homes dropped major cash on home furnishings; housewares sales were up 28% in the quarter ended August. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Bed Bath & Beyond also invested heavily in its online operations, especially in-store and curbside pickup. Digital sales were up 89% in the quarter. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture:</strong> B-cubed is a rare medium-sized, brick-and-mortar retail chain that's figured out how to dance in the Covid-19 rain. The pandemic has smiled upon big boxers like Walmart and Target, as well as digitally native rivals like Amazon. But peers like Macy's are struggling, <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-retail-bankruptcies-store-closures-hit-record-in-first-half-11601371800?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">or worse</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ Want to learn sweet retail lingo like B-cubed and even more insight?</strong> Read more in <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/retail/stories/2020/10/01/bed-bath-beyond-reversed-sales-slump?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Retail Brew</a>.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MARKETS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/01/two-companies-playboy-hims-join-spac-boom?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
We're Starting a SPAC
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Well, not yet...but would you be surprised? SPACs aka special purpose acquisition companies aka blank-check companies were the finance fad of the summer, and they're not planning on fading away with the daylight. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Two more companies said they're going public via mergers with SPACs yesterday: <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/01/hims-a-direct-to-consumer-health-company-is-going-public-via-spac.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Hims</a>, the direct-to-consumer healthcare company, and Playboy, a "<a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/01/investing/playboy-ipo/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">lifestyle brand</a>" that stopped printing its magazine back in February.  </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Quick explainer: </strong></span><span>A SPAC is a shell company that goes public and raises funds exclusively for the purpose of acquiring </span><span><em>another</em></span><span> company, taking it public in the process. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Because SPACs provide certain advantages (like making the process of going public a lot less time-consuming) they've had waves of popularity before—but nothing like 2020. SPACs have raised more than $41 billion so far this year, compared to $13.5 billion in 2019.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">One more sign of the times: </strong>The very first exchange-traded fund (ETF) for tracking SPACs <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-10-01/first-blank-check-etf-begins-trading-with-spac-mania-building?srnd=premium&sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">launched</a> yesterday and will be heavily weighted toward SPAC legends like DraftKings and Virgin Galactic.</p>

<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/10/01/irish-supreme-court-subway-rolls-dont-count-bread?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Subway: Sandwich Place or Cupcake Shop?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Subway storefront" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNjAwL3N1YndheV9zdG9yZWZyb250LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Omar Marques/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Here's what a Subway roll is, according to Morning Brew copywriter Henry Stockwell:</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;line-height: 22px;"><img src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNTk5L2hlbnJ5X3N1YndheV9saW5lX29uX3NsYWNrLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiJ9" class="img-responsive" width="640" style="width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;" alt="" data-reactroot=""></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">What it's not, <a href="https://abcnews.go.com/International/court-rules-subways-sandwich-bread-bread/story?id=73358543&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">according to</a> the Supreme Court of Ireland: bread. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory:</strong> In 2006, a Subway franchisee in Ireland <a href="https://www.bbc.com/news/business-54370056?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">applied</a> for a refund on taxes paid between 2004 and 2005, arguing that because its products include bread, a "staple food," it should be exempt. But the country's Revenue Commissioners refused to repay the franchisee, and the case made its way to the Irish Supreme Court. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And the Court decided...uh-uh. The justices ruled Tuesday that Subway bread is a "confectionary or fancy baked good," not bread. Under a 1972 law, the sugar in bread can't account for more than 2% of the weight of flour in the dough. In all of Subway's bread options, sugar accounts for 10% of the flour's weight. So the tax stands. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The defense: </strong>"Subway bread is, of course, bread," said a spokesperson.</p>

style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca Pacaso\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Pacaso house\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eWill Varner\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSigns you've made it: Three-ply toilet paper, ordering from a menu that doesn't have prices, and stepping into the foyer of your second home. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, startup Pacaso \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/as-pandemic-boosts-suburban-home-demand-startup-sells-a-new-ownership-model-11601553600?mod=business_featst_pos2\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eemerged from stealth\u003c/a\u003e to help you with pad No. 2. The brainchild of former Zillow CEO Spencer Rascoff and exec Austin Allison, Pacaso is pitching \"an entirely new category of second home ownership\" by selling \u003ca href=\"https://www.geekwire.com/2020/ex-zillow-leaders-including-spencer-rascoff-launch-startup-change-people-buy-second-homes/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epartial rights\u003c/a\u003e to a property, ranging from 12.5%–50%.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow it works: \u003c/strong\u003eImagine that a timeshare, commercial lease, and Airbnb had a baby. Interested buyers browse Pacaso's listings or find something on the market, then the company sets up the LLC, finds buyers for remaining shares, and handles the other logistics. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn exchange, Pacaso charges an upfront 10% fee and 1% annual maintenance fee.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePacaso launched with just four homes, but it's hoping to spread to 25 markets in the next year with a focus on suburbs and more affordable cities rather than beachfronts and resort towns. It's got $17 million in venture funding, including the backing of former Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz, and $250 million in debt.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThere are still some questions.\u003c/strong\u003e Like traditional vacation timeshares, Pacaso properties could see slower appreciation compared to a fully owned home, as well as bitter competition over who gets the house for the Fourth of July weekend. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eTiming couldn't be better \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eRascoff and Allison wanted to \"democratize\" second homes before the pandemic, but Covid-19 offered a perfect opportunity as city residents looked to swap subways for suburbs or upgrade their WFH offices. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eHome prices are now up 13% annually after four months of growth in new home sales and a \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/09/24/2020-residential-real-estate-sales-soar-mortgage-delinquencies?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esupply squeeze\u003c/a\u003e that's limiting inventory. Pacaso thinks it has the solution: Besides defraying the cost of home ownership, it would bring new units on the market by buying portions of existing second homes.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ereal estate experts think home buying enthusiasm could continue \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/real-estate-market-819e3c85-3765-4014-91c0-b545be6d5935.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efor years\u003c/a\u003e thanks to low interest rates and older millennials settling down with their first mortgage.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eJust when you thought Bed Bath \u0026 Beyond was out, pandemic trends and new leadership pulled it back in.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory: \u003c/strong\u003eBed Bath \u0026 Beyond was in a bad way last year, with \u003ca href=\"https://finance.yahoo.com/news/bed-bath-beyond-verge-epic-151648613.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ean ugly brawl\u003c/a\u003e between activist investors and the executive team. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut now? That investor tussle ended in \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/retail/stories/2019/12/18/bed-bath-beyond-sheds-csuite?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ea c-suite shakeup\u003c/a\u003e, including a new CEO, that's serving it well. The new guy, Mark Tritton, released quarterly earnings yesterday that beat expectations on both revenue and profit. Shares surged as much as 33%. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSo what happened? \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003ePeople stuck in their \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cspan style=\"text-decoration: line-through;\"\u003eCovid caves\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e homes dropped major cash on home furnishings; housewares sales were up 28% in the quarter ended August. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eBed Bath \u0026 Beyond also invested heavily in its online operations, especially in-store and curbside pickup. Digital sales were up 89% in the quarter. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture:\u003c/strong\u003e B-cubed is a rare medium-sized, brick-and-mortar retail chain that's figured out how to dance in the Covid-19 rain. The pandemic has smiled upon big boxers like Walmart and Target, as well as digitally native rivals like Amazon. But peers like Macy's are struggling, \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-retail-bankruptcies-store-closures-hit-record-in-first-half-11601371800?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eor worse\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory:\u003c/strong\u003e In 2006, a Subway franchisee in Ireland \u003ca href=\"https://www.bbc.com/news/business-54370056?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eapplied\u003c/a\u003e for a refund on taxes paid between 2004 and 2005, arguing that because its products include bread, a \"staple food,\" it should be exempt. But the country's Revenue Commissioners refused to repay the franchisee, and the case made its way to the Irish Supreme Court. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnd the Court decided...uh-uh. The justices ruled Tuesday that Subway bread is a \"confectionary or fancy baked good,\" not bread. Under a 1972 law, the sugar in bread can't account for more than 2% of the weight of flour in the dough. In all of Subway's bread options, sugar accounts for 10% of the flour's weight.
